text: is a Japanese athlete. She is best known as a long-distance runner competing mainly in the marathon. In 2008, she retired from racing."Sydney marathon champion Takahashi to retire," Agence France-Presse (AFP). 28 October 2008; retrieved 2012-7-20. ==Early life== Takahashi was not a successful runner in high school. She improved after she graduated from college.International Association of Athletics Federations (IAAF), "Takahashi, Marathon barrier- breaker, announces retirement," 29 October 2008; retrieved 2012-7-20. ==International competitions== ===Timeline=== * 1997: 5000m World Championships, 13th * 1997: Osaka International Women's Marathon, 7th place * 1998: Nagoya International Women's Marathon, 1st place, Japanese record at the timeSports Reference.com (SR/Olympics), "Naoko Takahashi" ; retrieved 2012-7-20. * 1998: Bangkok Asian Games, gold medal, Japanese record at the time * 2000: Nagoya International Women's Marathon, 1st place * 2000: Sydney Olympics, gold medal, current Olympic record * 2001: OHME Marathon (30 km), Japanese record at the time * 2001: Berlin Marathon, 1st place, World Record at the time * 2002: Berlin Marathon, 1st * 2003: Tokyo International Women's Marathon, 2nd * 2005: Tokyo International Women's Marathon, 1st * 2006: Tokyo International Women's Marathon, 3rd * 2008: Nagoya Marathon, 27th ==Related pages == * Sports in Japan * Japan at the Olympics ==References== ==Other websites== * Takahashi Naoko at IAAF Category:1972 births Category:Living people Category:Olympic gold medalists for Japan
title: Naoko Takahashi
